prefLabel.en: Tactical Combat Casualty Care (TCCC | TC3) Care Under Fire (CUF) Hemorrhage Control (HC) Experience API (xAPI) Profile; aka, TCCC CUF HC xAPI Profile

definition.en:
A profile derived from the xAPI Video CoP profile, scoped to the TC3 CUF HC content available from the deployed medicine website, and designed for programmatic generation of sensible, dense, and diverse xAPI datasets; datasets which include a multitude of emergent, reasonable, and repeatable patterns of behavior; behavior modeled within the TCCC CUF HC xAPI Profile as statement templates and patterns.

The xAPI Video CoP profile was chosen as a starting point for many reasons including:

1) it's the prevailing effort to model the video domain within the xAPI ecosystem
2) it has gone through several iterations, i.e., v1.0.3

The CoP, led by Pankaj Agrawal and full of talented xAPI community members, has conversed, debated, and pondered the design of the xAPI Video CoP profile since the groups formation. Their work is extremely valuable and serves as the shoulders upon which the current profile resides. Sadly, the TCCC CUF HC xAPI Profile statement templates no longer conform to the constraints of their ancestors - for several reasons; future work may alter this. As such, statements conformant to the TCCC CUF HC xAPI Profile are not required to include a reference to the CoP xAPI Video profile. Regardless, the influence of the xAPI Video CoP profile is found throughout this document.

The TCCC CUF HC xAPI Profiles' design enables an xAPI semantic modeling technique that currently the xAPI Video CoP profile does not. Using the v1.0.3 xAPI Video CoP profile as the basis for programmatic, xAPI profile based, statement generation -- via pattern and statement template definitions -- results in little more than noise and logical fallacies sandwiched in between video initializations and terminations. The CoP profile, along with other similar, low granularity, low complexity xAPI profiles; profiles which do not model --- well, generically and/or otherwise --- permutations of behavioral patterns; patterns implicit to the domains being modeled by the profiles; are not good candidates as they don't accurately reflect the domain they model, both as defined using xAPI and as demonstrated through xAPI profile based statement generation.

The authors of this profile understand that xAPI profiles can be intentionally designed in a way which is contextually rich and well designed, yet not appropriate as the basis for statement generation. The authors take no issue with intentful design, but are also quick to point out that inaccurate, inconsistent, misleading, and/or incorrect semantic modeling of a domain -- as an xAPI profile -- can be quickly identified within the trends, statements, and general characteristics of corresponding simulated xAPI datasets.

Model based data generation prevents poorly designed models from hiding -- as well -- behind the curtain of JSON-LD. This detection is contingent upon sufficient analysis of the simulation datasets as the analysis precedes understanding of a models properties and nuances. In some cases, that analysis consists of stepping through activity logs, while in other cases it involves filtering, transformation, aggregation, and/or visualization of xAPI data in order to describe some aspect of the model; and thus hopefully the real world. If a complex, domain specific, data generating processes can be replicated within simulation results via xAPI profile definitions, the pattern matching construct responsible can be utilized in a number of ways including:

a) continuous refinement and testing on novel datasets, i.e. tuning
b) data mining tasks once the corresponding model is tuned
c) KPI tracking or another live, event based form of tracking; can be implemented within streaming architectures or other information digital highways
d) additional ways not envisioned by the authors

The power of the generative technique lies in a positive feedback loop established by, and implicit to, iterative xAPI profile design when equipped with a tool that provides a means of easy experimentation and rapid prototyping. The ability to incorporate elements from real world datasets into this feedback loop strengthens the semantic domain modeling processes. The process of incorporating new sources of information into, and deriving data driven insights from these data sources can be automated in ways which promote and/or support autonomous refinement and background services such as anomalous pattern identification.

In general, xAPI profiles written for use within generation should contain:

1) patterns complex enough to enable programmatic generation of sensible xAPI learner pathways
   a) in the case of video; simple played, paused, resumed, and completed logic to prevent obvious logical fallacies in generated datasets
   b) diverse patterns which model a sufficient number of domain specific behavioral patterns and/or permutations within said patterns

2) high and low level statement templates
   a) definition of patterns common to a classification of things, i.e. statement templates with a low to medium amount of granularity or specificity
   b) definition of patterns specific to a thing, the classification of which may not be a factor, i.e. statement templates with a medium to high amount of granularity or specificity

This xAPI Profile is currently (2/20/2020) limited to interactions with TCCC CUF HC video content but this document may be returned to at a later date for additional work. Future work may expand upon the other phases -- i.e., 1, 3 and 4 -- and components -- e.g. TCCC ASM, Combat Casualty Care, etc. -- from the expanded TCCC universe. Major updates to this profile will be documented and handled in adherence to the xAPI Profile Specification and general best practices.

In closing, the current effort resulted in the derivation of non-trivial behavioral pathways, within the domain of video engagements, from the set of possible video interactions established by the CoP xAPI Video profile. These pathways are written in the abstract language of xAPI patterns and statement templates but are made more concrete through the incorporation of TCCC CUF HC video content. The videos themselves are defined as concepts where as the possible video interactions are defined as patterns that reference statement templates specific to said videos. This profile improves upon the Video CoP xAPI profile by providing an expansion of the video interaction behavior permutations, expressed as xAPI profile patterns. The expansion enables generation of datasets which will eventually pass some sniff test provided enough tuning and refinement of the definitions within this profile. In comparison, the dataset generated by the Video CoP xAPI profile is blown out of the water in terms of complexity, usefulness, and sensibility which is unexpected given the differences between the two xAPI profiles.

description.en-US: Introduction to Hemorrhage Control and Tourniquet application.
Thank you for participating in the TCCC ASM Course! Please take a moment to provide feedback.
The TCCC-ASM Course met the stated learning objectives.
This training motivated me to learn more about TCCC.
The course was presented in a way that helped me stay engaged in the learning process.
The materials I was provided during the course enhanced my learning.
The instructor(s) was(were) knowledgeable and prepared.
I received adequate attention from my skill station instructor(s).
The instructorsâ€™ explanations helped me understand the concepts and master these skills.
The presentation(s) was(were) the right length and provided the right amount of information.
The instructional videos helped me learn TCCC concepts and lifesaving skills.
I was given enough time and opportunities to practice each of the TCCC lifesaving skills.
The skills and exercises increased my confidence in delivering lifesaving interventions.
I am confident I can properly place a tourniquet on a casualty.
I am confident that I can pack a wound and apply a pressure bandage and help to slow or stop massive bleeding.
I am confident I can open an airway.
I am confident I can assess a casualty.
I understand how these concepts and skills might apply to real-world situations.

definition.en: When a student begins the All Service Members Tactical Combat Casualty Care Student Course Evaluation survey
When a student submits their feedback via the All Service Members Tactical Combat Casualty Care Student Course Evaluation survey
Lifecycle of the Intro Video
return one of the following templates: `:seeked`, `:vol-delta`, `:screen-delta` or `:cc`

prefLabel.en: Intro Video: Any Time After Init But Before Termination

definition.en: Zero or more Video Engagements that can happen regardless of play/pause state.
Things which can, but don't have to, happen to the video after initialization, but prior to termination.
after init, perform zero or more non-play actions potentially followed by a play action

prefLabel.en: Intro Video: After Init Prior Termination

definition.en: Possibly play video + cascading effects
Playing the video, potentially to completion
one pathway ends with a completion, one does not
A sequence of interactions which will terminate with a completion
A sequence of interactions which will not terminate with a completion
Zero or more engagements with the video after play has started prior to video completion

prefLabel.en: Intro Video: After Branch Prior Completion Zero+

definition.en: pause or perform any time video interaction

prefLabel.en: Intro Video: After Branch Prior Completion

definition.en: The pause event and the possible things which can follow
May result in a Played event serving to resume the paused video

definition.en: A sequence of interactions which will terminate with a completion
A sequence of interactions which will not terminate with a completion
Zero or more engagements with the video after play has started prior to video completion

prefLabel.en: Cat Buddy Routed: After Branch Prior Completion Zero+

definition.en: pause or perform any time video interaction

prefLabel.en: Cat Buddy Routed: After Branch Prior Completion

definition.en: The pause event and the possible things which can follow
May result in a Played event serving to resume the paused video
Lifecycle of the Soft Self Looped
return one of the following templates: `:seeked`, `:vol-delta`, `:screen-delta` or `:cc`

prefLabel.en: Soft Self Looped: Any Time After Init But Before Termination

definition.en: Zero or more Video Engagements that can happen regardless of play/pause state.

prefLabel.en: Soft Self Looped: Maybe Any Time

definition.en: Things which can, but don't have to, happen to the video after initialization, but prior to termination.

prefLabel.en: Soft Self Looped: Optional After Init

definition.en: after init, perform zero or more non-play actions potentially followed by a play action

prefLabel.en: Soft Self Looped: After Init Prior Termination

definition.en: Possibly play video + cascading effects
Playing the video, potentially to completion

The video profile of the xAPI was created to identify and standardize the common types of interactions that can be tracked in any video player.
Indicates the actor paused the video being played at a specific point.
Indicates that the actor started experiencing the recorded media object.
Indicates the actor changed the progress towards a specific point.
A recording of both the visual and audible components made available on a display screen.
The actual length of the media in seconds. Value MUST be a float value with maximum 3 decimals.
Used to identify the loudness of sound specified for a media object.
A list of concepts reused from an older version (1.0) of the Activity Streams specification.
Indicates that the actor has started the object. For instance, when a person starts a project.
Indicates that the actor has submitted the object. If a target is specified, it indicates the entity to which the object was submitted.
AcrossX Profile
The single representation of a specific page number and the content on that page in any digitally or physically written material.
A list of vocabulary concepts originally created in the TinCan registry.
To indicate an actor has passed over or omitted an interval, screen, segment, item, or step.
